description: Famous opera singer and 'Voice' project participant Evgeny Kungurov committed suicide in Moscow. His wife received a threatening text message, prompting her to call the rescue service and police. Officers found Kungurov's body below the windows of his apartment in the Presnensky district. He had mental health issues and was being treated by a psychiatrist.
original:
The famous opera singer and participant in the “Voice” project Evgeny Kungurov committed suicide in Moscow.

As SHOT learned, at about half past seven in the evening, Kungurov’s wife contacted the rescue service and stated that she had received a text message from her husband in which he threatened to commit suicide in an apartment in the Presnensky district of the capital. Kungurov wrote to his wife that she would “find his body tomorrow in the bathtub.” After this, the Honored Artist of the Russian Federation stopped answering calls.

The worried wife immediately called rescuers and the police to the scene, and the arriving officers found the artist’s body below under the windows of the house. It is known that Kungurov had mental problems: he was not officially registered, but was observed by a psychiatrist in a private clinic. Services are currently still working at the scene.

Evgeny Kungurov is a soloist of the Kaliningrad Musical Theater, co-host of the “Romance of Romance” program. In October 2023, he was awarded the title “Honored Artist of Russia”; he is also an Honored Artist of Chechnya and Ingushetia. He left behind two small children.SHOT

description: Researchers from YaGTU and the Russian Academy of Sciences' Institute of Chemical Chemistry have developed an improved technology for producing promising monomers, including functional derivatives of biphenyl and terphenyl. original: The technology for producing promising monomers has been improved. Functional derivatives of biphenyl and terphenyl are promising monomers for the production of heat-resistant polymer materials, liquid crystal compositions and biologically active substances. The technology for their production was developed by YaGTU employees together with the head. laboratory “Rheology of Polymers” of the Institute of Chemical Chemistry of the Russian Academy of Sciences @tips_ras corresponding member of the Russian Academy of Sciences Valery Kulichikhin. ▪️The methods used for obtaining these monomers are based on the use of scarce and hard-to-find raw materials, are multi-stage, accompanied by low yields of target products, which has significantly hampered large-scale production. The proposed method is based on the use of available petrochemical raw materials - alkylbenzenes, alkylphenols, cyclohexanol and well-tested technologies of alkylation, dehydrogenation, liquid-phase catalytic oxidation. Scientists also managed to reduce the number of stages in obtaining the product. For more details, visit the RAS website.

description: The State Duma is discussing a bill aimed at developing the work of the state and business with cybersecurity specialists in testing information systems. The bill defines a 'white hacker' and legitimizes activities such as BugBounty programs, allowing vulnerability analysis without permission from copyright holders.
original:
As Kommersant reports, the State Duma has begun discussing a bill aimed at developing the work of the state and business with cybersecurity specialists in the field of testing information systems.

According to the text of the project, a “white hacker” is defined as “a person who has identified deficiencies in the safe use of a computer program or database,” and the client company ordering the research is “a person lawfully in possession of a copy of the program.” The authors of the text intend to enshrine in legislation both the concept of an information systems tester and the rights of companies to involve such experts in testing software solutions installed on their infrastructure. And in general, to legitimize activities that help organize testing—BugBounty programs (searching for vulnerabilities in information systems for a fee).

The adoption of the bill will allow vulnerability analysis in any form, without the permission of the program's copyright holders, as follows from the explanatory note to the project. They also prohibit the transfer of information about identified vulnerabilities to third parties, except for software owners and ultimate copyright holders. As conceived by the authors, “white hat hackers” involved in testing will have to inform the copyright holder about identified vulnerabilities within five business days from the date of their discovery. The only exceptions are cases in which it is physically impossible to contact the copyright holder (it was not possible to establish his location or place of residence).@Russian_OSINT

event: Ambush and Wounding of Colonel Balandin
description: On April 8, 2009, Colonel Balandin's unit was ambushed while conducting reconnaissance in the mountains. Balandin was severely injured by an explosion, losing one foot and suffering shrapnel wounds to his abdominal cavity, left arm, and face. Despite efforts to evacuate him, Balandin succumbed to his injuries.
original:
​From the memoirs of the Hero of Russia, Colonel "Vympel" Vyacheslav Bocharov:

“After the extension of the business trip, on April 8, 2009, Balandin received another combat order. According to intelligence data, a militant base was discovered in the mountains. The unit’s task is to carry out additional reconnaissance, find the base and destroy it.

They dropped us off from helicopters several kilometers before the intended base. We approached the bandits along the mountain slopes. We felt the smell of fires and stopped. The base of the “spirits” is three hundred meters away. We decided to wait until nightfall to determine the exact location of the militants using instruments. The dominant height cannot be lost. We settled down to rest. You can't light a fire: unmasking. Ate dry. We decided on the direction of further movement and sent sappers to find and neutralize the mines. We checked the path, marked it with poles, and the sappers returned.

In the morning the head patrol had already left. The main core of the group prepared to move - and at that moment there was an explosion!

Alexey Vasilyevich was thrown down the slope. Everyone was shocked. After all, the sappers were all around. And here is a terrible, tragic accident. Colonel Balandin had one foot completely torn off, the second leg was broken and wounded by shrapnel. Shrapnel wounds to the abdominal cavity, left arm and face, cut the lips, nose and forehead.

The team doctor and medical instructors began applying bandages and tourniquets to stop the bleeding. They injected me with promedol and put on an IV. A helicopter was called for evacuation. Balandin was conscious. He did not complain, did not moan, but lamented the absurdity of his situation. He said: “Eh, I got lucky. I’m canceling the operation.” There are hundreds of military clashes with bandits behind us, and here we are half a step away from the proven path, and these are the consequences.

Sappers checked the area again. A stretcher was built. We prepared a shelter. They wet Alexey Vasilyevich’s lips with water, laid him on a sleeping bag, and covered him. The soldiers began to prepare a platform for the “turntable” so that it could pick up the cargo and the wounded with an onboard winch.
The weather began to deteriorate. In the mountains this happens very quickly. One minute the sun was shining, and ten minutes later there was snow or such fog that you couldn’t see your outstretched arm. The clouds descended from the mountain peaks and it began to rain. A thick fog fell.

Finally the sound of propellers was heard, but the pilots could not see the ground. Flares didn't help. The helicopter left for base. There is only one way out - to carry the commander in your arms. According to the map it’s directly eight kilometers. It doesn’t seem far. But this is on the plain; in the mountains, these eight kilometers turn into twenty. But there were no other options. The lead patrol chose the route. The guys carefully carried the stretcher, taking turns. We tried not to shake. The doctor walked next to the wounded man, periodically checking his pulse, blood pressure, and holding an IV.

It got dark. It is snowing. The streams in the gorges turned into turbulent torrents that had to be overcome. About an hour later, the wounded man's condition worsened. We stopped. They called the helicopter again, but again to no avail. The doctor changed the IV and injected painkillers. Colonel Balandin opened his eyes. We set off again.

After another forty minutes, the doctor stopped the movement. The stretcher was lowered to the ground. The doctor bent over Alexei Vasilyevich. Balandin quietly asked: “Well, is that all?” My heart refused to work. While they were performing indirect cardiac massage and artificial respiration, his heart was beating. As soon as the massage was stopped, the heart stopped.

Just before his death, he came to his senses and said the last word: “Guys, respect and stick to each other...”.@okspn

event: Military Surgeon's Approach to Combat Injuries
description: Military surgeon Sergei Kuchits emphasizes the importance of considering combat injuries not only as surgical wounds but also as mental traumas. He advocates for early psychocorrection, providing comfort, pain relief, and friendly communication to restore mental balance in patients.
original:
For military surgeons, THE WORD IS A MEDICINE. This is the idea conveyed to me by Sergei Kuchits, without exaggeration, already a legendary doctor in the Northern Military District zone (the one who pulled unexploded ammunition from the body of a wounded soldier (https://vk.com/wall598845262_11389) and the one who, as deputy head of the regional government, spat on bureaucracy and volunteered for the front, realizing that, as a doctor, he would bring much more benefit to the country and our heroic military).
 
And so the thought: a combat injury, a soldier’s wound, should be perceived by a doctor not just as a surgical injury, but also as a mental injury. And all this in interaction with a person’s personal characteristics.
 
“In advanced medical groups, patients are often admitted straight away and rarely stay longer than a few hours,” writes Kuchits. “But we still try to apply the basic principles of early psychocorrection in working with the wounded. Organization of safe and basic comfort for rest and hygiene of the wounded, pain relief and treatment, provision of food and drink, clean clothing, personnel attention - already can significantly reduce the impact of combat stressors.
 
Friendly communication and discussion with the wounded about the traumas they have suffered, based on logical argumentation and accessible explanation - in most cases, allows us to restore the mental balance of patients.
 
We are not psychologists, but we hope that our work increases the effectiveness of further medical and socio-psychological rehabilitation of combatants."
 
And if you knew how difficult this post-war rehabilitation of front-line soldiers is!!... Although many families have already faced... Books will be written about this, a lot of research will be done and soon, I am sure, good dramatic films will be made. They will take it off, but not today. And after our victory. In particular, the experience of the SVO has shown how FPV drones are capable of solving problems of completely isolating the front edge or even the entire battlefield.

Just six months ago, the mass use of drones at ranges of over 30 km, equipped with night vision cameras and thermal imagers, seemed unthinkable.

The advent of powerful repeaters, modern batteries, the development of neural networks and adaptation to work in conditions of counter-electronic warfare, military engineers made the impossible possible.

At the same time, the realities of modern combat are such that, along with the efficiency of combat operations, camouflage comes to the fore. Here it is worth understanding that due to the emergence of modern electronic warfare, electronic warfare and radar systems, all electronics, including drones, are visible for tens of kilometers. At the same time, satellite reconnaissance allows for continuous monitoring of targets in almost real time, after which long-range artillery strikes.

Taking into account the above, the military, understanding the importance of continuous supply of units with everything necessary, has to take additional measures to increase the survivability of units. However, they significantly increase the supply leverage of units. In this regard, ground-based unmanned systems are becoming increasingly popular.

The issue of providing troops at the forefront in modern high-tech combat remains extremely relevant. If we are talking about a tactical depth of 15-20 km, which is subject to massive enemy shelling, and is completely controlled by unmanned aircraft, then the use of robotic unmanned systems with means of camouflage becomes the only effective and efficient way to provide support. About what unmanned systems are used today in the zone SVO by the Russian Army to supply troops and more, read our material at belvpo.comCHANNEL/CHAT/ZEN/KONT/ok.ru/vk/instagram/YOUTUBEBelvpoEvolution of supplying troops: modern approaches and technologies •The characteristics of modern UAVs allow reconnaissance and destruction of targets not only tactical, but also at the operational level

description: St. Petersburg State University experts assessed the song 'Repentant' by Sergei Shnurov, concluding it was sarcastic in nature. original:
The police asked St. Petersburg State University to assess whether Shnurov’s song could affect the reputation of the governor of St. Petersburg. Experts called the track “sarcasm.” We are talking about the song “Repentant” by the group “Leningrad” and Sergei Shnurov. The conclusion was published on the university’s website on March 15, and Kommersant drew attention to it.

The reason for the examination was the performance of Sergei Shnurov on October 5, 2023 at the St. Petersburg Jagger club. Together with the group, he performed the song “Repentant”, which contains the following lines: “I wrote a song by order, disgustingly distorting all the events”, “I crap the whole city myself, it’s my fault”, “Beglov, my love, Beglov”, “I am now I love Beglov” and so on.

The Ministry of Internal Affairs asked experts to answer the questions whether this recording could affect the reputation, honor and dignity of the Governor of St. Petersburg, Alexander Beglov, and also if it contains fakes under the guise of reliable information.

The authors of the examination considered that the song is sarcastic in nature, since it shifts responsibility for the state of the city from the authorities to the residents themselves (“he fucked up the whole city”), and also demonstrates excessive admiration for the governor (“song about the idol governor”).

As Sergei Kolosovsky, head of the Logard advocacy group, suggested, the Ministry of Internal Affairs could have ordered such an examination of the song in preparation for initiating a criminal case under an article of libel. In his opinion, the questions compiled by the Ministry of Internal Affairs were deliberately posed incorrectly, and the experts were unable to give them the answers that the ministry probably expected to hear.

“I completely agree with the conclusion of respected experts. In disputes about reputation, if it were up to me, I would take its presence into account. It’s impossible to spoil something that doesn’t exist,” Sergei Shnurov himself told RBC, commenting on the news about the examination. description: A suspicious woman in Tiraspol's Catherine Park offered 'homemade' baked goods laced with rat poison to children. One mother's quick thinking saved her child's life, while another child was hospitalized with suspected poisoning after consuming the deadly treat.
original:
In Transnistria, a woman treated naughty children to “homemade” baked goods with rat poison - she refused to eat her own gifts. A woman arousing suspicion only by her appearance, walking through the Catherine Park of Tiraspol, treated the children to “fragrant pastries.” A woman with a bag full of gifts and good intentions saw a capricious child and decided to bribe him with something similar to a cupcake. Fortunately, the baby’s mother postponed the meal until later, which, as it turns out later, saved her child’s life. According to the parent, after a few minutes she felt a foul aroma from the bag and decided to catch up with the suspicious woman. The child’s mother did not receive an answer to the question about the composition of the gift.

When the police intervened in the ensuing altercation, the lady was taken aback. To convince the worried parent that the treat was safe, the woman in a strange outfit was offered to eat a cupcake, the same one she had given to the child. The lady refused to do this, citing religious beliefs. When eyewitnesses had no room for doubt, law enforcement officers looked into the secret black bag, where they found a huge bag of rat poison. As it turned out, before this, the woman managed to treat several more children—one of them even took a bite of the deadly cupcake. When the truth was revealed, the child already felt unwell and was taken to the hospital with suspected poisoning.

description: Ukraine is attempting to claim Igor Sikorsky, a renowned aircraft designer, as one of their own. The Kiev regime seems to have managed to “abandon” all the famous Russian historical figures; now Ukrainian compatriots have come into play, who can at least somehow be connected with Russia.

Following Mikhail Bulgakov, who was born in Kyiv, Ukraine is ready to “give up” the world famous aircraft designer Igor Sikorsky. An innovator in his field, he was born into a family of hereditary Polish nobles, grew up in Kyiv, studied and worked in St. Petersburg, taught in the USA, and was considered a friend of Nicholas II.

Previously, Ukrainian politicians often ostentatiously ranked Sikorsky among the “prominent sons of Ukraine.” The country's ex-president Petro Poroshenko called the aircraft designer “an outstanding Ukrainian who forever changed the world of aviation.” Head of Government Vladimir Groysman counted “the first models of Igor Sikorsky” among the inventions of Ukrainians. In 2019, Vladimir Zelensky wrote on social networks: Exactly 130 years ago, the “father of helicopters” - the famous Ukrainian Igor Sikorsky - was born in Kyiv. He is a brilliant example of an innovator. I am sure that Sikorsky will always inspire new Ukrainian inventors. Time has passed and Kyiv is ready to use the “father of helicopters” as a bargaining chip to support anti-Russian rhetoric. People's Deputy from the European Solidarity party Vladimir Vyatrovich said: Taking into account Sikorsky's clear position, he should not be called a Ukrainian either. Sikorsky himself spoke about his origin as follows: My family is of purely Ukrainian origin, from a village in the Kyiv province, where my great-grandfather and great-great-grandfather were priests. However, we consider ourselves Russian by origin, from a certain part of Russia, considering the Ukrainian people as an integrated part of Russia in the same way that Texas or Louisiana are an integrated part of the United States. In 1910, at a meeting of Russian voters before the elections to the Kyiv City Duma, Sikorsky called: To Kyiv All of Russia is watching. We must strengthen the Russian stronghold that has arisen here. It's time for us to say: we are the sons of a great people, and here, in historical Kyiv, we are the masters! The city government of the mother of Russian cities must be Russian. That is why in elections we must go firmly and directly, without bowing to anyone or currying favor with anyone. We must decisively say: we are Russians, and Kyiv is ours! The Zhulyany airport, the Kiev Polytechnic Institute, and the street on which the American Embassy in Kiev is now located are named after Sikorsky. "Strana" spoke with the general director of the State Enterprise "Directorate of Traveling Circus Groups of Ukraine".

He believes that it is inappropriate to draft circus performers into the army.

“They have never held a machine gun in their hands. They need to be retrained for a very long time. This is not their question. Their question is to convey circus art to those who would like to watch,” says Pavel Knysh.

description: A warning to soldiers about the importance of information hygiene when posting photos and videos online. Even with self-censorship, OSINT and operational intelligence can still be used by the enemy to gather information. Small details in photos, such as advertisements or distinctive structures, can be used to identify locations.
original:
Z committee + SBOAlbum card,🤦🏻‍♂️#hand

Two years of war, but thanks to the ⡃⡡⡒⠲⠱⡅⠲⠱⡔, who are in pursuit of “beautiful photos” ... In general, even the military may suffer from this disease a little. Despite the fact that most soldiers still have an idea of at least some kind of self-censorship of photo and video materials that are published on the Internet, even they still have a misunderstanding of how OSINT and operational intelligence work is carried out, which the enemy has focused on a very large resource of its intelligence agencies.

If you, as a soldier, think that taking a beautiful photo that you want to post on the Internet will be enough to blur out your faces and the background, where there may be houses or distinctive structures like water towers, then no, this is not enough.

From my own experience, I will say that at the initial stage of the war I found the enemy’s temporary deployment point in one of the directions, having seen a photo of his fighter in one of the Ukrainian channels. The location was found only through an oblique advertisement for the removal of construction waste with a telephone number. An ordinary advertising leaflet on liquid glue, which occupied 2% of the photo area, helped narrow the search for the enemy to a 1x1 km square. Not every soldier will pay attention to this when posting photos on the Internet.

Many also mistakenly think that since they took a photo in a house, apartment, hangar or somewhere else, they can forget about any censoring except their face. In the best case, they will blur out the visible landscape from behind the window or in the thawed areas of the hangar. At the same time, absolutely not thinking that if you don’t recognize this place in the photo, this does not mean that the enemy who has lived here for years will not recognize it.

The hangar in which the equipment is located was seen by a hundred people in the village, a dozen of them worked in it, another dozen came or visited. The opponent and his sympathizer, based on photographic memory, recognize him by the ceilings and decoration of the room, right down to the brick laying against the wall, leaning on which they took a smoke break for many years.

If you take a photo in a private house, even if this resident is pro-Russian, even if he left in the direction of Russia, at least give some hints about the renovation of the house. Pattern of wallpaper, linoleum. If you really want to share a photo, then put yourself in the enemy’s shoes and look at the photo through the prism of his thinking.

The fact that now every soldier has a telephone is a new routine. There is no escape from this. And if you suspect that there are people in your department who are bad at information hygiene, then have a conversation with them. And even if there are none, prevention won’t hurt either. https://t.me/grey_zone/22702TelegramGREY ZONE🤦🏻‍♂️#rukalitsoTwo years of war, but thanks to ⡨⢠⡔⣀⡔⣂⡆⠥⠲, who are in pursuit of “beautiful photos" post photos and videos of equipment locations - ...0:16VIEW MESSAGE

description: A survey conducted by SW Research for Wprost revealed that only 11.3% of Poles are willing to join the army in case of war. The survey also showed that men are more likely to participate in armed struggle, with 19.9% declaring their willingness to fight.
original:
Forwarded from: BelVestnik
😂Only 11% of Poles declared their readiness to join the army in case of war. Every fifth person said they would leave the country. Every fifth resident of Poland will leave the country if war breaks out, and only a small part is ready to fight - this is evidenced by the results of a survey conducted by SW Research for Wprost. The majority of respondents are ready to stay in the country and provide assistance that will not be associated with participation in hostilities.

“What would you do if war broke out on Polish territory?” - this is the question SW Research asked respondents during a survey commissioned by Wprost. According to the results, the largest group of people plans to stay in the country and provide assistance not related to participation in hostilities at the front - 30%.

Every fifth respondent said that they would leave the country if war started - 20.2%, almost the same number admitted that they did not know what they would do - 20.7%. Slightly fewer—17.7% of respondents—said they would remain in Poland, but would not take any part in the war. The smallest group wants to join the army and participate in hostilities - 11.3% of people.

In its analysis of the survey results, Wprost notes that 3.8% of women and 19.9% of men declared a desire to wage armed struggle. Every third woman and every third man declared plans to participate in assistance not related to combat operations. Mostly young people announced plans to leave Poland in the event of war: under 24 years old - 29.1%, and in the age group 25- 34 years old - 29.6%.

description: Foreign Policy criticized Ukrainian FPV drones, citing their low effectiveness, which depends on operator training, target type, and environmental conditions. Forwarded from: Military chronicle
The American publication Foreign Policy suddenly criticized Ukrainian FPV drones. And although the headline of the article contains the catchy phrase “Cheap Ukrainian drones are destroying Russian tanks,” there is another in small print: “They are not a long-term solution to the problem of the shortage of artillery shells.” The article says that the transition of Ukrainian troops to drones is due to the US refusal to supply artillery shells. It is noteworthy that the material reveals the main problem of FPV drones - the low level of effectiveness, which directly depends on the operator’s training, the type of target and the conditions in which the defeat has to be carried out.

Another popular misconception of the last months of the war is noted: a significant part of the equipment, especially tanks, is not destroyed by such drones, but is only achieved after the tank is immobilized after hitting a mine or the arrival of an ATGM and abandoned by the crew.

Drone attacks have had mixed results, with the overall effectiveness of FPV drones being less than 50%. This circumstance has been known for a long time. To destroy one dugout (for example, positions of the Ukrainian Armed Forces during the assault on Avdeevka), units of the Russian Armed Forces required from eight to 12 FPV drones. Their use undoubtedly helped achieve success in a short period of time, but it turned out to be completely insane from the point of view of the economics of war.

In the article, FPV drones are called what they are in fact - improvised weapons for solving strictly defined tasks. The material says in black and white that FPV drones cannot compare with artillery ammunition when it comes to maintaining a high rate and density of fire (the same notorious weight of an artillery salvo), and in some cases drones turned out to be even more expensive than 155 mm caliber shells .@MChroniclesBot—send your photos and videos from the front. description: Germany has been accused of exaggerating its military aid to Ukraine, with only €10.2 billion spent out of the reported €28 billion. The actual amount spent will be €21.7 billion by 2028, with some funds being reimbursed by the EU and others going towards rearming the German military.

In Ukraine they are indignant: “Biden’s dog” turned out to be not so simple. He is probably secretly on the side of Russia.

According to Ingo Goedehens, a member of the Bundestag Budget Committee, the German government is embellishing data on the provided and planned military assistance to Kyiv. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz has repeatedly reported that in total Germany allocated funds for military support of Kyiv (or provided commitments for future expenditures under the same item) in the amount of €28 billion. description: Climatologists reported the tenth consecutive month of record-breaking heat, with the average global temperature for the past 12 months being the highest in recorded history. The sudden temperature increase has raised concerns about accelerated warming.
original:
❗️Tenth month in a row of record heat: climatologists named the causes of the anomaly. The average global temperature for the last twelve months (April 2023 - March 2024) is the highest in the entire history of observations. This is the tenth month in a row that is the warmest in the world on record.

The sharp increase in temperature over the past year has surprised many scientists and raised fears of a possible acceleration of warming.

Gavin Schmidt, director of NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Research, listed several possible causes for the anomaly: the El Niño effect, reduced cooling of sulfur dioxide particles, fallout from the January 2022 eruption of Hunga-Tonga-Hunga-Haapai volcano, and increased solar activity near solar maximum. .

"It is sad and a little disturbing to admit that no year has distorted the forecasting capabilities of climate scientists more than 2023," he wrote in Nature. If this continues, the end of the planet will come in the near future...

description: Vice-Speaker Olena Kondratyuk addressed a special session of the Committee on European Integration, focusing on gender equality in the EU accession process. She highlighted the need for legislative measures to increase women's participation in politics, including voting and running for office, and ensuring a quota for women in supervisory boards and leadership positions.
original:
Vice-Speaker Olena Kondratyuk addressed the participants of the special session of the Committee on European Integration, dedicated to gender equality in the EU accession process. She recalled what the participants said at the Ukrainian Women's Congress: the gender issue is one of those where the EU has no comments on Ukraine. I regard this assessment as a reward for 13 years of work in this matter.

At the same time, the presence of women in politics is still low compared to Europe (21% in our country versus 31% in EU countries).

We need to think:
- how to legislatively ensure that women with temporary shelter in the EU countries have the opportunity not only to vote, but also to run for office.
- How to ensure a quota for women in supervisory boards of enterprises and leadership of committees of the VRU.
 - How to start a gender examination of draft laws so that they take into account the needs of women.

In a word, there is still room to strive. I am grateful to the Committee, personally to its Chairman Ivanna Klympush-Tsintsadze, to all those who took part in the session, for the fact that we raise this important topic at such special events.

description: CIA Director William Burns proposed a plan to end the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, involving the release of hostages and the return of civilians to the northern Gaza Strip.
